sect1.title: 147 Nematodes
sect1.para: HARSHA SHEOREY, BEVERLEY-ANN BIGGS, AND RICHARD S. BRADBURY

Nematodes are unsegmented cylindrical worms with a body cavity containing an alimentary canal and genital system; the sexes are separate. They have longitudinal muscles, which allow them to move by flexing their bodies. There are four or five larval stages and the adult worm. In most instances, the third-stage larva is the infective stage.

Intestinal nematodes include the soil-transmitted helminths (STHs), which are among the most common infections globally with more than 1.5 billion people infected, especially in tropical and subtropical regions and in resource-poor settings where sanitation is inadequate. These parasites are a major cause of poor health, with the greatest morbidity in women and children, and are included in the list of Neglected Tropical Diseases by the World Health Organization (WHO) (1). By definition, STH infections refer to ascariasis, trichuriasis, and hookworm. Although Strongyloides stercoralis also has a soil-transmitted cycle, it differs from most other helminths in its capacity to reproduce within a human host. However, there has been a compelling argument that the control of strongyloidiasis should be promoted in conjunction with STH control programs (2, 3). Control measures for strongyloidiasis are now being included in many STH treatment programs in areas of endemicity (3). In developed countries, groups such as immigrants and refugees, travelers, and war veterans often unknowingly harbor intestinal helminths for years after leaving an area of endemicity. This has implications for provision of health services and necessitates action to formulate guidelines for managing infections that are not commonly seen in these countries (e.g., guidelines formulated within Australia [4]). Chronic morbidity in humans from STH infections can be reduced by periodic treatment with anthelmintics in high-risk populations. In particular, global efforts to target STH infections in children with school-based chemotherapy have reduced the prevalence of infection in many lower- and middle-income countries (3; http://www.who.int/intestinal_worms/en/). However, monitoring and evaluation of treatment programs is labor intensive, and newer technologies are needed for assessing program effectiveness. Deworming programs need to distinguish between populations where parasitic infection is controlled and those where further treatment is required. Where possible, the use of real-time PCR (quantitative polymerase chain reaction or similar high-throughput molecular diagnostics) has been suggested in this context due to its improved sensitivity and specificity when compared to traditional microscopic methods (5).

Conventional laboratory diagnosis is based primarily on microscopic examination of feces and differentiation of species based on morphology of eggs or larvae detected (Fig. 1 through 3). The sensitivity of microscopy is influenced by the method of processing, e.g., direct microscopy, formalin-ethyl acetate concentration, Kato-Katz smears, or mini-FLOTAC (University of Naples Frederico II, Naples, Italy), and is affected by factors such as variability of the number of eggs or larvae excreted. Occasionally adult worms may be processed by histology, and anatomical features of both the adult worm and the eggs may be used in identifying the parasite (Fig. 4 and 5).

Molecular diagnosis for intestinal nematodes (including real-time multiplex PCR; 6) is increasingly being introduced in diagnostic laboratories. There are issues with sensitivity of assays forStrongyloides in particular (7); in chronic infection, numbers of larvae may be low and they are intermittently excreted in feces. The number of eggs produced by a single adult female Strongyloides is estimated at only 30 to 50 per day. This exceptionally low yield compared to the output of the STH worms accounts for some of the diagnostic difficulties encountered in screening for this species. In research studies, real-time PCR on a single fecal sample has compared favorably to quadruplicate Kato-Katz microscopy performed on 2 separate days and shows markedly improved sensitivity in patients with low-burden STH infection (8). The sensitivity of real-time PCR assays is dependent on the assay chosen, and some commercial multiplex panels appear to have a sensitivity equivalent to, or slightly lower than, microscopy concentration methods in early evaluations (9). It should be noted that the method of sample preservation, transport and storage temperature, and choice of DNA extraction method will affect the sensitivity of STH real-time PCR assays (10). The inclusion of a bead-beating step in the DNA extraction stage is necessary to ensure optimal sensitivity (9).

sect1.para: The subject of preventive chemotherapy has recently been updated by WHO, 2017 (1). Global trends and management options for Strongyloides infection (including screening and prophylaxis of at-risk groups) are available (11–13).
For details about susceptibility testing for parasites, consultchapter 155.

sect1.title: Taxonomy of Nematodes
sect1.para: There are a variety of morphological features and DNA sequences which form the basis for taxonomy of nematodes. At the anterior end, mouth parts may possess structures for attachment or penetration. These may include spines, hooks, or cutting plates. The pharyngeal cavity may be short, hollowed out, or long and hairlike. Esophageal shape also varies but usually ends in a muscular bulb. In the male, features of the tail may include caudal papillae and copulatory spicules (sclerotized copulatory aids) or bursa. Studies strongly suggest that nematodes are actually related to the arthropods and priapulids in a newly recognized group, the Ecdysozoa. All these nematodes belong to Kingdom Animalia, Phylum Nemathelminthes (Nematoda). The nematode infections described in detail in this chapter are by no means exhaustive but include those commonly associated with human infection on a worldwide scale. This chapter is confined to consideration of the soil-transmitted helminths (includingS. stercoralis) and Enterobius vermicularis. From time to time, other less common species may be encountered, and the assistance of reference laboratories covering both human and veterinary diagnostic services may be required.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Specimens should be collected before antibiotics or antiparasitic drugs are given (for details, refer tochapter 137). It is important to transport and process feces specimens for parasitic examination as soon as possible following collection. Clinicians and collection staff should be encouraged to send fresh specimens to the laboratory without delay. It should be noted that formalin-based fixatives will damage DNA and may not allow subsequent molecular analysis. If delay is inevitable, specimens should be refrigerated or transported in commercially available vials or kits with a preservative recommended by the testing laboratory. If these are not available at the point of collection, preservative should be added as soon as the specimen is received in the laboratory. Excellent directions for proper collection are available with these kits. Discussion on which preservative to use depends on various considerations such as whether permanent-stained smears or immunoassays are required. Two or three specimens collected over a period of 7 to 10 days is optimal. Specimens that are very small in volume or obviously dry should be rejected and a fresh specimen should be collected. Refrigeration and the use of preservatives should be avoided if agar plate culture (APC) or Baermann procedures for culture of Strongyloides larvae are required (for details, see reference 14).

Helminths (or other worms) retrieved at colonoscopy or submitted by the patient should be transported to the laboratory without delay. Worms can be preserved in 60% alcohol; avoid the use of formalin, as it causes contraction and hardening of tissues. Adult worms should not be histologically sectioned, as this will often impair accurate species identification.

For sputum specimens, proper instructions should be given to patients emphasizing requirements, i.e., avoidance of saliva, and avoiding use of a mouthwash before deep coughing (expectorating). Sputum and aspirates should be transported to the laboratory and processed immediately.
All specimens should be handled using standard precautions, e.g., latex gloves should be worn by anyone handling the specimens.

sect2.title: LABORATORY METHODS
sect2.para: The specimen should be handled in a work cabinet (biological safety cabinet), and gloves and gown should be worn. Examine the specimen and note its consistency. Look for any motile or nonmotile worms (Fig. 4A, B). Select and sample areas that look watery, purulent, or bloody. If feces are formed, sample from several areas of the specimen for the concentration technique.

Both the direct specimen and concentrate are examined as wet preparations in saline and iodine. However, iodine is generally not recommended when looking for helminth eggs, as it may darken them and may be difficult to recognize. Scan the whole coverslip area at low-power magnification (×100). Most helminth eggs and larvae can be identified at this magnification and diagnosis can be confirmed at high power (×400) on the basis of their shape, size, and characteristic features (Fig. 1 to 3). Smears should be prepared from a centrifuged deposit (500 × g, 10 minutes) for permanent staining, but this technique is not the preferred method for identification of nematode eggs or larvae; it is primarily to diagnose mixed infections with protozoa. Some commercial diagnostic gastrointestinal helminth multiplex real-time PCR panels now incorporate Ascaris primers (9).

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Ascaridida and the familyAscarididae.

Of the three genera of ascaridid nematodes regularly occurring as parasites of humans, onlyAscaris is a true human parasite. The others (Toxocara and Toxascaris) are common parasites of cats and dogs that occasionally infect humans. Ascaridids are related to anisakids, with three distinct lips, but differ in that their life cycle is linked to terrestrial rather than aquatic conditions.
Ascaris suum was once thought to be a separate species in pigs but has since been found to be genetically similar to the human species A. lumbricoides (15).

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: Eggs ofA. lumbricoides (Fig. 2A to C) are usually seen in two forms: unfertilized and fertilized. The egg shell of a fertilized egg (45 to 75 by 35 to 50 μm) consists of an inner lipid layer responsible for selective permeability, a chitin-protein layer responsible for structural strength, and an outer vitelline layer. The inner layer contains a lipoprotein, ascaroside, which helps prevent formaldehyde, disinfectants, and other chemicals from contacting the embryo. The outer corticate surface of the fertilized egg has an uneven deposit of mucopolysaccharide with adhesive properties (Fig. 2A). This corticate outer surface may not be present in some eggs (Fig. 2B). Eggs appear brown due to staining by bile. The unfertilized eggs have thinner walls and distorted mammillations. These eggs are usually more elongated in shape, measure 85 to 95 by 43 to 47 μm, and may have either a pronounced mammillated coat or little or no mammillated layer. Although rare, unfertilized eggs may be seen (Fig. 2C).

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: During an incubation period of 2 to 3 weeks in soil, first-stage larvae develop inside the eggs and molt to form the second-stage larvae. Following ingestion of eggs, the larvae hatch in the jejunum; these second-stage larvae have a typical filariform appearance (measuring approximately 250 by 14 μm). They migrate across the intestinal wall and enter the circulation to reach the lungs, growing to approximately 560 by 28 μm. A further molt occurs in the lungs, and the larvae develop over 8 or 9 days to reach a size of 1.2 mm by 36 μm. They are carried up the airways to the throat and are swallowed. Growth is rapid after the fourth and final molt in the intestine.

sect2.title: Worms
sect2.para: Adult male and femaleA. lumbricoides worms (Fig. 4A) are colored light brown-pink when fresh, turning white with storage in ethanol/formalin-based fixatives. Egg laying commences at 8 to 9 weeks when females measure 15 to 20 cm, and they may reach 45 cm by 5 mm; males are generally smaller at 15 to 31 cm by 3 mm. Males have a curved tail containing a cloaca, a pair of copulatory spicules, and caudal papillae. Adult worms live in the lumen of the small intestine and feed on digestion products.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Prevention
sect1.para: A. lumbricoides infection is one of the most common human infections, with approximately 800 million people estimated to be infected (16). It has a worldwide distribution but is most common in tropical and subtropical areas. It is particularly associated with crowding and poor sanitation. Contamination of soil by human excreta can result in a layer of eggs within silt that is easily disturbed, resulting in contamination of root and vegetable produce.
Preventive measures consist of health education about personal hygiene and sanitation, and drug therapy.

sect1.title: Transmission and Life Cycle (Fig. 6)
sect1.para: Eggs passed in feces (diagnostic stage) have an unsegmented ovum; this develops in the soil over 10 to 15 days to reach an infective-stage larva (Table 1). Eggs may survive in this form for years under favorable conditions of heat and humidity. Infection follows the ingestion of embryonated eggs (infective stage) that hatch in the small intestine. Larvae penetrate the intestinal mucosa, and the venous circulation carries them to the lungs. From here they migrate to the trachea and are swallowed. They then complete their development into mature adult worms in the small intestine, with eggs produced after 60 to 70 days. A minority of individuals develop heavy infections and act as an important source of transmission.
The prepatent period (from egg ingestion to egg production) is approximately 2 months.

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: Initial infection is usually asymptomatic. Migration of larvae through the lungs may result in an eosinophilic pneumonitis with cough, fever, and dyspnea. This may occur up to 2 weeks after infection and lasts approximately 3 weeks. Bronchospasm can be prominent and, although rare, may be fatal.

The clinical features in established infections relate to the worm burden. Most infections are light and asymptomatic, but nonspecific abdominal symptoms may occur. Heavy infections are associated with malnutrition and impaired growth in children. Intestinal obstruction is an uncommon complication in children with a very large worm burden and may have a high mortality rate in some settings (3). Ectopic ascariasis occasionally occurs when adult worms attempt to escape the gut lumen. This may be a spontaneous event or may occur in response to febrile illness, medication, or anesthesia. Worms may enter hepatobiliary and pancreatic ducts or the appendix and cause obstruction, resulting in biliary colic, cholecystitis, acute cholangitis, acute pancreatitis, appendicitis, or a hepatic abscess. It occurs more commonly in countries with high rates of infection where the parasite is endemic. For more on the clinical manifestations of A. lumbricoides, see reference 17 and Table 2.
Peripheral blood eosinophilia may be seen at different stages of larval migration (Table 3).

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: The primary diagnosis of infection is by demonstration ofA. lumbricoides eggs in feces. The fertilized eggs are round to oval, bile stained, mammillated, and thick walled and 50 to 80 μm long by 40 to 60 μm wide. Both fertilized and unfertilized eggs may be found in the same specimen; fertilized eggs are more elongate (up to 90 μm) than unfertilized eggs. Multiple specimens taken on separate days may be required. Concentration methods such as formalin-ethyl acetate sedimentation or saturated solution flotation methods should be used for optimal yield. Decorticated fertile and infertile eggs may be difficult to recognize (Fig. 2B and C). Motile larvae may sometimes be seen in expectorated sputum, usually during the initial lung migration stage.

sect2.title: Macroscopic Examination
sect2.para: Occasionally, an adult worm may be passed in feces or may spontaneously migrate out of the anus, mouth, or nares, particularly in children.

Identification is relatively straightforward due to the large size and distinctive morphology ofA. lumbricoides. However, it should be noted that earthworms of comparable size can occasionally be retrieved from toilets and submitted for identification. The distinguishing features of Ascaris adult worms are that they have tapering ends (Fig. 4A), a lateral white line along the entire length of the body, three lips at the anterior end, and a tough cuticle.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect2.para: Commercial or in-house assays are now available to detectA. lumbricoides DNA directly from feces. The inclusion of a bead-beating step prior to fecal DNA extraction is advised to ensure the sensitivity of any PCR assays for A. lumbricoides eggs.

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Albendazole is the first choice for treatingA. lumbricoides, and mebendazole is also effective (see chapter 153 and references 1 and 17). Pyrantel and piperazine are also effective and can be used in pregnancy (see chapter 153 and references 1 and 17).

listitem.para: Parasitic eosinophilia is a hematologic reaction to tissue invasive stages of helminth (worm) infection.
Two protozoans,Cystoisospora and Sarcocystis, rarely may cause a mild eosinophilia in some patients.

Helminth infections that cause eosinophilia, in travelers or otherwise, are listed below. Acute disease in travelers 4 to 6 weeks post freshwater exposure mimics other undifferentiated tropical fevers, but no eosinophilia is seen in malaria, typhoid, arboviral infection, amebiasis, or rickettsial disease.
Ectoparasite infection (e.g., crusted scabies) may sometimes cause eosinophilia.
Differential diagnosis consists of drug reactions and other nonparasitic medical conditions (malignancies, fungal infections, skin diseases).
Strongyloides (eosinophilia may be absent, especially in compromised hosts)
Lymphatic filariasis (especially tropical pulmonary eosinophilia)
Toxocara (visceral larva migrans)
Trichinella (ingestion of uncooked game meat)

listitem.para: Hookworm
Fasciola (right upper quadrant pain)

para.emphasis: Occurs at various stages of infection:

listitem.para: Schistosomiasis
Cysticercosis (seizures or raised intracranial pressure)

Other human and non-human filarial worms (Dirofilaria, Mansonella)

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Oxyurida and the family Oxyuridae. Only the genusEnterobius of this family regularly occurs in humans and other primates.

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: Pinworm eggs (Fig. 2F) are ovoid, 50 to 60 by 20 to 35 μm, and asymmetrically flattened on one side, and appear colorless when recovered from the perianal skin. The outer layer of the egg shell is albuminous and sticky, enabling the egg to adhere readily. The egg contains an immature first-stage larva, but this develops rapidly to become infective.

row.entry: Symptoms relate to worm burden; most infections are light and asymptomatic; migratory phase, eosinophilic pneumonitis
Demonstration of eggs in feces; identification of worm passed; eosinophilia low or absent

listitem.para: History of passing/vomiting worm
Mild gastrointestinal symptoms
Small-bowel obstruction in children with heavy worm burdens
Ectopic ascariasis involving appendix or hepatobiliary or pancreatic ducts
Malnutrition and growth retardation in children

row.entry: Many infections are asymptomatic; pruritus ani occurs mainly at night; excoriation from scratching and secondary infection are common; general symptoms include weight loss and loss of appetite; occasionally ectopic, involving appendix or female genital tract
Demonstration of eggs in “sticky tape” preparation; eosinophilia low or absent
Pruritic rash or “ground itch” on extremities at site of entry of larvae; migratory phase, cough and wheezing due to eosinophilic pneumonitis
Demonstration of eggs or larvae in feces; culture (agar plate method or Harada-Mori technique); eosinophilia usually moderate

listitem.para: Iron-deficiency anemia
Hypoproteinemia leading to chronic malnutrition and growth disorders in children
Enteropathy with gastrointestinal symptoms
Light infections may be asymptomatic

row.entry: Chronic infection occurs due to autoinfection; recurrent, migratory, linear rash when larvae enter perianal skin, or “larva currens”; urticarial rashes also occur; enteropathy causing intermittent or chronic diarrhea, sometimes with malabsorption; pulmonary symptoms and hypereosinophilia may occur during autoinfection; Loeffler-like syndrome; Gram-negative-bacterial septicemia or meningitis due to transfer of bowel microbiota by migrating larvae; hyperinfection syndrome (disseminated) in immunocompromised or debilitated individuals, leading to severe enteropathy and respiratory symptoms

Demonstration of larvae in feces; culture (agar plate method or Harada-Mori technique); demonstration of antibodies in serum; eosinophilia variable but usually moderate; PCR, high specificity but variable sensitivity

Usually asymptomatic or mild gastrointestinal symptoms; epigastric pain, vomiting, distension, anorexia, and weight loss;Trichuris dysentery, sometimes with rectal prolapse, may occur in heavy infections; growth retardation in children due to chronic malnutrition and anemia
Demonstration of eggs in feces; eosinophilia low or absent

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: The larvae hatch in the small bowel, then migrate to the large bowel to complete molting and development.

sect2.title: Worms
sect2.para: Adult female worms (Fig. 4B and C) measure approximately 8 to 13 by 0.3 to 0.5 mm, with cervical alae or winglike expansions at the mouth and a long, pointed tail (hence the name pinworm). Male worms are 2.5 to 5 mm by 0.1 to 0.2 mm but are rarely seen (Fig. 4D).

Enterobius gregorii was thought to be a sister species of E. vermicularis, and has a slightly smaller spicule (sexual organ). However, it is now believed that E. gregorii likely represents an immature stage of E. vermicularis.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Prevention
sect1.para: E. vermicularis infection has a worldwide distribution and is more common in children than adults. Preventive measures consist of health education about personal hygiene and sanitation, and drug therapy.

sect1.title: Transmission and Life Cycle (Fig. 7)
sect1.para: Adult worms inhabit the cecum, appendix, and ascending colon. The female migrates down the colon when mature and deposits eggs on perianal and perineal skin (diagnostic stage). More than 10,000 eggs may be deposited, become infective within 6 h (Table 1), and remain viable for up to 5 days. Eggs are sticky on deposition, but after drying they lose this quality and become well suited to dissemination in dust (18). It is assumed, though not proven, that the female reenters the rectum after egg deposition (19).

Transmission is either via autoinfection, direct from the anal and perianal regions to the mouth, usually by fingernail contamination, or from exposure to dust in a contaminated environment. When swallowed, the embryonated eggs (infective stage) hatch in the small bowel. Larvae migrate to the large bowel, where they mature into adult worms. Retroinfection occurs when hatched larvae migrate from the anal skin back to the rectum (18).

figure.title: FIGURE 7 Life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect1.para: The prepatent period (from egg ingestion to egg production) is 3 to 4 weeks.

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: Children are most commonly infected. Many patients are asymptomatic or present with pruritus ani and perineal pruritus, which may be severe and worse at night. Excoriation from scratching and secondary bacterial infection is often evident. With heavy worm burdens, poor concentration, enuresis, and emotional distress are features. General symptoms, including abdominal pain, weight loss, and loss of appetite, may occur. Occasionally, the presence of worms in the appendix contributes to inflammation and true appendicitis (20). Reinfection (autoinfection or retroinfection) is also possible.

The presence of ectopic worms and eggs in several sites, including the female genitourinary tract, the epididymis, and the peritoneum, has been reported. Some of these mimic tumor-like lesions (21) or endometriosis. They rarely cause serious complications. For more on the clinical manifestations of E. vermicularis, see reference 17 and Table 2.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: The primary diagnosis of infection is by demonstration of the presence of eggs on the skin in the perineal area by using the “sticky tape” method (eggs adhere to cellulose tape and can then be detected microscopically). Briefly, a strip of cellulose tape, folded onto a microscopy slide with adhesive side outwards, is pressed firmly against the right and left perianal folds, preferably early in the morning. The tape is then spread back over the slide with the adhesive side down and examined directly under the microscope. Visibility of eggs can be improved by lifting the tape from the slide, adding a drop of xylene or xylene substitute, and pressing the tape back down on the slide. This helps clear the preparation, and the eggs can be observed clearly (22, 23). If a frosted tape is submitted by mistake, a drop of immersion oil on the top of the tape will clear it enough for microscopy. Repeated preparations on 2 to 3 consecutive days may be required. Commercial collection kits (Evergreen Scientific, Los Angeles, CA, or Swube [Becton Dickinson], Sparks, MD) are available in some countries. Eggs are occasionally present in feces. Eggs are non-bile stained, ovoid, asymmetrical with a characteristic shape (concave on one side and flat on the other), smooth, and thick walled and may contain a partially or fully developed larva (Fig. 2F). Specimens should ideally be taken early in the morning prior to the child’s bathing or using the toilet.

sect2.title: Macroscopic examination
sect2.para: Adult female worms may be seen in feces, observed around the anal opening, or detected at colonoscopy. They are white or cream-colored, pin- or threadlike worms. In rare instances, immature worms that lack the winglike expansions at the mouth may be detected in feces. The mature, distended female contains copious eggs, and these may be extruded from the genital pore by applying pressure to the coverslip (Fig. 4C). The cross-section view of the adult female shows characteristic eggs in histology section (Fig. 5A). Lateral alae that run the length of the body in both male and female worms can be seen and can also be seen in histological sections.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect2.para: Commercial or in-house assays are now available to detect DNA directly from feces.

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Albendazole, mebendazole, or pyrantel pamoate are drugs of choice. These drugs should be avoided in early pregnancy. Piperazine is also effective and can be used in pregnancy but has lower efficacy (seechapter 153 and references 1 and 17).
It is important to treat other family members and close contacts and to decontaminate the environment by washing bed linen and clothes. Advice should be given on adequate hygiene and hand washing.
For a summary ofE. vermicularis, see Table 2 and Table 4.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade V (Chromadoria: Rhabditina) of the Nematoda, in the order Rhabditida (Strongylida) and the familyAncylostomatidae.

Ancylostoma and Necator are the two genera of Ancylostomatidae that infect humans. Infective species include Ancylostoma duodenale (Old World hookworm), Ancylostoma ceylanicum (mainly described from Asia and the Pacific Islands) (27), and Necator americanus (New World hookworm).

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: Eggs (Fig. 2D) of A. duodenale, A. ceylanicum, and Necator americanus are practically indistinguishable; they are oval shaped with a thin shell and measure approximately 56 to 75 by 36 to 40 μm. They have a clear space between the developing embryo and the thin eggshell. When passed, eggs are only at the four-cell stage. Development of larvae occurs in moist, shady, warm soil, where larvae hatch within 1 to 2 days.

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: First-stage rhabditoid larvae (Fig. 3C, E, and G) from the hatched eggs measure about 200 μm in length. The have a long buccal cavity (Fig. 3E) and an inconspicuous genital primordium. They feed on organic debris and undergo two further molts over a 5- to 8-day period. The infective, nonfeeding third-stage larvae measure from 500 to 700 μm. The larvae are ensheathed and have a esophagus:intestine ratio of 1:3. Ancylostoma larvae are generally longer than those of Necator and have a tail that gradually tapers to a rounded end, while N. americanus has a rapidly tapering tail ending in a point. The oral cavity of N. americanus filariform larvae is clearly visible and rhomboid, while that of A. duodenale larvae is less conspicuous. The sheath of N. americanus filariform larvae has prominent transverse striations; these are less prominent in A. duodenale. These infective filariform larvae remain viable in the soil for several weeks. Variations in the morphology of the filariform larvae have been used to differentiate A. duodenale from N. americanus, but are of no clinical significance as these are not freshly passed in human feces. The common dog hookworm Ancylostoma caninum may infect the human intestinal tract, but generally does not reach maturity, though it may cause eosinophilic enteritis (24). Recent reports of infections of humans with sexually mature A. caninum from South Africa (25) and India (26), based only on molecular identification of eggs passed in feces, require further investigation.

sect2.title: Worms
sect2.para: For all three species, male worms (5 to 11 mm) are shorter than females (7 to 13 by 0.4 to 0.5 mm), andA. duodenale is generally longer and more sturdily built than N. americanus. The three hookworm species infecting humans can be differentiated on the basis of their anatomical differences in mouth parts and caudal and buccal anatomy. Adult worms are rarely seen since they remain firmly attached to the intestinal mucosa, feeding on blood obtained by puncturing the capillary network in the intestinal mucosa.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Prevention
sect1.para: An estimated 740 million people are infected in impoverished regions of the tropics and subtropics, especially in Asia, Latin America, the Caribbean, and sub-Saharan Africa (3). A. ceylanicum, although previously considered to be largely a parasite of cats and dogs, is prevalent in humans in Southeast Asia and is also reported from the Pacific Islands (27, 28). Additionally, in a study conducted in Cambodia, sequencing of the cytochrome oxidase-1 gene has identified two groups of A. ceylanicum, the first apparently restricted entirely to infections in humans and the second group including isolates from humans and dogs, thus confirming that A. ceylanicum represents a true zoonosis (29). In addition to drug therapy, preventive measures consist of health education about personal hygiene, the need to wear shoes, and avoidance of soil with possible fecal contamination. A double-blinded, randomized, controlled, dose-escalation phase 1 clinical trial confirms that coadministration of the two hookworm vaccine candidates is safe and well tolerated in children (30).

figure.title: FIGURE 8 Life cycle of hookworms. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect1.title: Transmission and Life Cycle (Fig. 8)
sect1.para: Eggs are passed in the feces into the environment, where they hatch into rhabditiform larvae that mature into filariform larvae, with potential to infect new hosts. Entry of third-stage or filariform larvae (infective stage) by direct penetration of the skin initiates human infection; within 10 days this is followed by migration to the lungs.A. duodenale larvae can also infect if swallowed, to result in direct maturation to the adult stage in the anterior small intestine. In contrast, larvae of N. americanus require an obligatory lung migration to initiate infection. Larvae leave the lungs after 3 to 5 weeks, travel up the airways to the trachea and pharynx, then enter the gastrointestinal tract and attach to the intestinal mucosa, where they mature into adults (Table 1). Attachment and the release of anticlotting factors results in blood loss and is greater with A. duodenale. Hookworms may survive in the host for several years. The prepatent period from larva penetration to egg production is 4 to 8 weeks.

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: The major clinical manifestation of hookworm infection is iron-deficiency anemia due to intestinal blood loss and depletion of iron stores. The degree of iron deficiency induced by hookworms depends on the intensity and duration of infection, the species of hookworm, and the iron status of the host. It has been estimated that a singleA. duodenale worm can withdraw as much as 0.2 ml of blood per day, whereas N. americanus withdraws approximately 0.05 ml. A. ceylanicum has also been recorded as causing a similar jejunal infection with associated anemia. In other cases, infection has been limited to the lower gastrointestinal tract, with symptoms more comparable to those seen with A. caninum eosinophilic enteritis (24). Young children, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women are most at risk for iron-deficiency anemia because of inadequate dietary iron and reduced iron reserves. Anemia during pregnancy is linked to maternal morbidity and mortality, impaired lactation, and prematurity and/or low-birth-weight infants. In children, iron-deficiency anemia may be associated with impaired neurocognitive development, reduced school performance, and exercise intolerance.

Patients with light worm burdens are usually asymptomatic. Moderate and heavy worm burdens cause epigastric pain and tenderness, nausea, weight loss, and diarrhea. This may lead to protein-losing enteropathy and hypoalbuminemia. In those who develop iron-deficiency anemia, common symptoms are lethargy and fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and palpitations. In children, chronic malnutrition and developmental delay may occur.

A pruritic rash is often present at the site of penetration of larvae (“ground itch”). This must be differentiated from cercarial dermatitis and creeping eruptions from other causes. In some patients, mild cough and wheezing occur in response to larval migration through the lungs. For more on the clinical manifestations and review of hookworms, see references17 and 31 and Table 2.
Peripheral blood eosinophilia may be seen at different stages of larval migration (Table 3).

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: The primary diagnosis of infection is by detection of eggs in feces. Multiple specimens taken on separate days may be required. For optimal yield, both direct and concentration methods such as formalin-ethyl acetate sedimentation or mini-FLOTAC should be used. Eggs are non-bile stained and usually have a 4- to 8-cell-stage embryo (Fig. 2D). Occasionally, a 16- to 32-cell-stage embryo or a developing larva may be seen, especially if there is delay in processing an unfixed fecal specimen. Hookworm eggs may be confused with Trichostrongylus eggs, but eggs of the latter species are more elongated (Fig. 2E), often have a unipolar tapering, and generally are in an advanced stage of cleavage upon passage. Some zoonotic helminths of primates, such as Oesophagostomum spp., Strongyloides fuelleborni, and Ternidens deminutus, may also be confused with hookworm eggs, though the size of these eggs does not fall within the normal hookworm egg size range (32).

sect2.title: Culture
sect2.para: Baermann sedimentation or culture for the detection ofStrongyloides stercoralis larvae by the Harada-Mori technique or agar plate methods may also demonstrate the presence of hookworm larvae (see “Strongyloides stercoralis” below for details) (Fig. 3C to G). Hookworm larvae can be differentiated from Strongyloides stercoralis larvae by their morphological features (Fig. 3A to G). Hookworm larvae are uncommon in freshly passed and adequately fixed fecal specimens, but motile larvae may be seen occasionally in expectorated sputum.

sect2.title: Macroscopic examination
sect2.para: Usually the worm is firmly attached to the small bowel mucosa, and they are rarely passed in feces. Worms may be detected during gastroscopy or colonoscopy and a specimen may be recovered. The adult worm can be identified by the structure of the buccal capsule and the morphology of the male bursal rays.
The diagnosis of hookworm infection should be considered in people who have resided in areas where the infection is endemic, especially if they have eosinophilia or iron-deficiency anemia.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect2.para: Real-time PCR has been shown to have a higher sensitivity than microscopy for the detection of hookworm infection, particularly in low-intensity infections. This approach has the added advantage of allowing species-level identification. Some recently released commercial diagnostic helminth multiple real-time PCRs incorporateN. americanus and Ancylostoma spp. primers (9).

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: The two most practical and effective drugs for treating hookworm infections are albendazole or mebendazole. These benzimidazoles should not be used in the first trimester of pregnancy and in children <12 months of age. Pyrantel pamoate is also effective and can be used in pregnancy (seechapter 153 and references 1 and 17).
Iron supplementation may be required for those who are iron deficient.
For a summary of hookworms, seeTable 2 and Table 4.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade V (Chromadoria: Rhabditina) of the Nematoda, in the order Rhabditida (Strongylida) and the familyStrongylidae.

Members of the familyStrongylidae exhibit an irregular alternation of generations, with a parasitic parthenogenetic female alternating with a free-living sexual generation. Only one genus, Strongyloides, occurs in humans.

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: Eggs of the parasitic female are deposited within the mucosa of the small intestine and usually hatch within the crypts of Lieberkuhn before reaching the lumen. As a result, they are rarely excreted in the feces (Strongyloides fuelleborni fuelleborni, seen in Africa and Asia, and Strongyloides fuelleborni kellyi, found on the island of New Guinea, are the exceptions; see below). Eggs of the free-living adult female are partially embryonated and oval in shape and measure approximately 50 to 70 μm in length.

figure.title: FIGURE 9 Life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: First- and second-stage rhabditiform larvae (Fig. 3A, B, and D) measure approximately 180 to 380 by 14 to 20 μm and are characterized by a muscular esophagus comprising the anterior third of the body. A short buccal cavity (Fig. 3A and D) and a prominent genital primordium located midbody (Fig. 3B) help to distinguish them from morphologically similar nematodes such as hookworms (Fig. 3C and E). In the soil, rhabditiform larvae follow a direct or indirect course of development. In the direct cycle, larvae develop rapidly into infective third-stage filariform larvae; in the indirect cycle, first-stage larvae develop into third-stage rhabditiform larvae and then moult to free-living adult male and female worms. Third-stage filariform larvae are 400 to 700 by 12 to 20 μm, and the ratio of eosophageal to intestinal length is approximately 1:1. The tail of the larva has a subtle v-shaped notch (Fig. 3F and G) but may be difficult to see.

sect2.title: Worms
sect2.para: Parasitic male forms do not occur. Parasitic females are small and thin, measuring approximately 2 to 3 mm in length and 30 to 50 μm in width. The anterior portion is thinner than the posterior and contains the esophagus.

The free-living adult female is approximately half the size (1 to 1.5 mm) of its parasitic counterpart, although nearly twice as thick (approximately 85 μm). While the reproductive systems are morphologically similar, the uterus in the free-living adult female contains significantly more eggs. The free-living adult male is slightly smaller than the female (0.95 to 1.2 mm) and approximately 55 μm in width, and has prominent paired spicules at the posterior end. The free-living stage ofS. stercoralis only exists for one generation, and all progeny become infective filariform larvae (33).

Transmission occurs when filariform (infective-stage) larvae penetrate the skin or mucous membranes and enter the venous circulation. Larvae may migrate directly through the organs to the gut or may be carried through the circulation to the lungs, where they penetrate alveolar walls, migrate through the tracheobronchial tree, are swallowed, and then embed within the mucosa of the upper small intestine. Here, they reach maturity and commence egg production by the process of parthenogenesis. The eggs hatch within the intestinal crypts to release rhabditiform larvae, most of which are excreted in feces (diagnostic stage) (33).

Some rhabditiform larvae develop into infective filariform larvae in the bowel lumen or crypts of the anus and maintain a cycle of repeated migration either by penetration of the mucosa of the colon or small intestine or externally by crossing perianal skin, to repeat the cycle of maturation within the same host. This process of autoinfection results in chronic infections that may persist for 40 years or more. The prepatent period (from larval penetration to egg production) is 2 to 4 weeks.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Prevention
sect1.para: Strongyloides live in warm, moist soil and are widely distributed in the tropics and subtropics, with distribution similar to hookworms. Strongyloidiasis still occurs among underserved or marginalized communities in some high-income countries and temperate regions of the world (34–38), including some regions of the United States (34, 35). There are an estimated 386 to 614 million patients infected with S. stercoralis worldwide (39, 40). Analysis of the limited prevalence data available identifies the geographical distribution and risk factors for Strongyloides infection. In particular there are hotspots for infection identified, especially in Southeast Asia (41). However, the true prevalence is uncertain due to the low sensitivity of conventional methods typically used for the detection of other STH infections. More sensitive methods such as the Baermann or APC method are required to detect the variably low numbers of larvae typically excreted in chronic infection (2, 42). At-risk groups include those living in areas where the parasite is endemic, and immigrants and refugees, indigenous peoples, and war veterans previously exposed in these regions (43, 44). Screening and active treatment of patients undergoing immunosuppression should be considered for at-risk groups (11–13). Patients with hyperinfection syndrome also pose an infection risk for immediate family, laboratory workers, and those providing nursing care.

Preventive measures include good personal hygiene and wearing shoes in areas where transmission occurs. Comparison of genotypes ofS. stercoralis isolated from dogs and humans has illustrated that one genotypic clade of S. stercoralis is found in dogs and humans, while another is found in dogs only, raising the possibility that dogs may represent a zoonotic source of infection (45).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: S. stercoralis infections are often chronic, lasting for several decades. Most patients have low worm burdens and are asymptomatic or have intermittent cutaneous and/or gastrointestinal symptoms. Intermittent or chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain and bloating, nausea, and anorexia are the main gastrointestinal symptoms. Other manifestations (e.g., dermatological, pulmonary) are less common.

Recurrent pruritic, slightly serpiginous, erythematous rashes may develop rapidly due to larval migration in the skin (“larva currens”). These are seen most commonly on the buttocks, groin, and trunk; movement under the skin is relatively rapid (several centimeters per hour) and may continue for 1 to 2 days. Other, less distinctive urticarial and papular rashes also occur. In contrast, cutaneous larva migrans due to animal hookworm species is very serpiginous and develops very slowly over weeks to months. Although pulmonary symptoms are uncommon in uncomplicated strongyloidiasis, passage of larvae through the lung may be associated with a cough, wheezing and dyspnea, and patchy infiltrates upon radiography (Loeffler-like syndrome).

In chronic infection it is thought that there is a balance between immunity and the level of infection. However, this equilibrium may be lost when illness or drug therapy leads to immunosuppression. Exacerbation of symptoms can occur in as little as 6 days after commencement of treatment with corticosteroids. The resulting disseminated strongyloidiasis or hyperinfection syndrome has a very high fatality rate (33, 45, 46). Other conditions predisposing to these syndromes include chemotherapy, HTLV-1 infection, alcoholism, kidney disease, bone marrow transplantation, and hypogammaglobulinemia (17, 37).

In disseminated disease, migration of larvae extends to multiple organs, and this can be associated with bacteremia and even meningitis caused by Gram-negative bacilli carried from the gut during migration of the larvae. Hyperinfection results from proliferation of worms with no spreading beyond the normal pattern of migration. Large numbers of larvae (and occasionally embryonated eggs) in stool and sputum produce severe gastrointestinal and/or respiratory symptoms (47). Within the bowel, the range of symptoms include generalized inflammation, colitis, proctitis, and mucosal ulceration. Most cases of strongyloidiasis associated with solid organ transplantation have been due to the reactivation of a latent infection in the recipient as a result of the immunosuppressive therapy; however, donor-derived infections are becoming increasingly frequent (48). Current practice guidelines need to be updated to incorporate immunological and molecular techniques for the rapid screening for strongyloidiasis prior to transplantation, and empirical treatment with ivermectin should be considered (43).
For more on the clinical manifestations ofS. stercoralis, see references 17 and 49 and Table 2.

sect1.title: Laboratory Detection
sect1.para: The laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis can be difficult (50, 51). Microscopy, including concentration techniques, has low sensitivity for the detection of strongyloidiasis (50). Diagnosis is based on demonstrating the presence of the larvae in feces, detecting DNA by real-time PCR, or demonstrating antibodies to S. stercoralis in blood. The choice may be based on practicalities in different clinical settings (52, 53). Currently, serology is the optimal screening method, but will not detect all cases. A combination of serology, APC, and PCR may be necessary for selected cases (51, 54).

sect2.title: Microscopy and Culture
sect2.para: Microscopy of feces may detect the rhabditiform larvae; eggs or adult worms are very rarely detected in cases with very heavy infection. In chronic infection, the sensitivity of microscopy is generally low, as larvae are shed sporadically and numbers depend on the stage and severity of the infection. For this reason, multiple specimens collected over several days should be examined. Coproculture is an alternative method of detection of larvae in freshly passed stool specimen. Ideally, this should be attempted for all suspected cases, especially with patients from areas where the infection is endemic. It is important that the specimen be sent directly to the laboratory, without refrigeration or addition of preservative. The critical factor in culture methods is that large quantities of stool can be processed. This improves the sensitivity compared with standard procedures such as formalin-ethyl acetate concentration or Kato-Katz smear. Care should be exercised in the handling of these cultures, as the larvae present are filariform or infectious and capable of crossing intact skin. The various methods available for culture are as follows (for details, see references14).

sect3.title: Agar Plate Culture
sect3.para: A large amount (2 to 3 g) of unrefrigerated feces is placed on the center of a nutrient agar plate, and the plate is sealed and incubated at room temperature. If larvae are present, they travel away from the initial inoculum, carrying bacteria from the feces. Colonies of these bacteria appear on the surface as tracks (or occasionally inside the agar) with a characteristic sinusoidal pattern (Fig. 3H). The plates are examined under a dissecting microscope for confirmation of the presence of larvae. For safety, larvae should be recovered in a solution containing formalin or ethanol to allow confirmation of identity. This is the most sensitive, safest, and most acceptable culture method to perform in a laboratory and is now the recommended procedure.

sect3.title: Harada-Mori Technique
sect3.para: The unrefrigerated fecal specimen is smeared on the top of a strip of filter paper, then dipped into 3 ml of water in a 15-ml sealed centrifuge tube. The tube is held at 25°C in the dark. After 7 to 10 days the water can be tested by microscopy for the presence of larvae.

sect3.title: Petri Dish Methods
sect3.para: Petri dish methods use either filter paper or a watch glass to hold the specimen. The larvae migrate to fresh water and light.

sect3.title: Baermann Technique
sect3.para: The Baermann technique is a modified funnel device that allows sampling of the water used to moisten the fecal specimen placed on a wire mesh covered with gauze. It relies on the principle that larvae will actively migrate out of the feces to fresh water and higher temperature.

Occasionally, hookworm larvae may hatch in feces that have been left at warm temperatures for long periods before processing. In contrast withS. stercoralis, these rhabditiform hookworm larvae have a long buccal cavity and inconspicuous genital primordium (Fig. 3A to E). The presence of larvae of Strongyloides in expectorated sputum or duodenal aspirate via an enteroscope may also be demonstrated. Filariform Strongyloides larvae may be seen in feces or sputum in cases of hyperinfection or in cases in which infection has been identified by the culture methods described above.

sect3.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect3.para: Diagnosis by molecular techniques has been developed (55) and is now available in many reference laboratories. Various formats for detecting DNA in feces such as real-time PCR, LAMP, and nested PCR have been shown to be useful (56–58). Overall, the specificity is very high, but the sensitivity is variable due to low numbers and intermittent excretion of larvae in feces during different phases of the infection. Good reviews comparing different testing protocols are available (7). Recently developed commercial diagnostic multiplex real-time PCR assays for the detection of gastrointestinal helminths include Strongyloides genus primers.

sect3.title: Other Tests
sect3.para: Although peripheral blood eosinophilia is common, especially during an initial acute infection, it does not reliably correlate with infection and may be intermittent in chronic infection. Eosinophil count may be used post treatment along with serology (60). The concomitant use of steroids may significantly decrease eosinophilia in infected patients (61) (Table 3).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Demonstration of anti-Strongyloides antibodies in blood should be used as a screening test or as an adjunct for diagnosis. In most cases it is useful in monitoring treatment. Antibody levels decline after 6 to 12 months of effective treatment and may be negative by 12 to 24 months (61, 62). It should be noted that a small number of patients with active infection (especially those immunocompromised) will not generate detectable antibody responses, and therefore APC or PCR may be necessary to include in any diagnostic algorithm. Multiple commercial and noncommercial diagnostic ELISA assays are available, employing crude S. stercoralis or Strongyloides ratti larval antigens or newer recombinant antigens such as NIE (31 kDa antigen). The sensitivity and specificity of these assays vary by antigen, but are generally between 75 to 94% and 82 to 96%, respectively (63). Dried blood spots have been shown to be a useful specimen in remote areas (64). Sensitivity may be lower in severely immunocompromised patients. Cross-reactions in patients with filarial and other nematode infections may occur. If antibodies are detected, efforts should be made to establish a parasitological diagnosis (microscopic and culture) and to exclude infection with other parasites that could result in cross-reacting antibodies. Strongyloides serology should be performed for all at-risk candidates for immunosuppressive therapy (see below). Assessing the accuracy and sensitivity of serological methods is difficult because of the lack of sensitivity of a fecal-based reference (“gold”) standard. Point-of-care lateral flow assays are also being developed; however, the specificity and sensitivity of these may be lower than the standard ELISA techniques (65).

listitem.para: Low specificity compared to microscopy and PCR, so should be used as an adjunct to diagnosis
Sensitivity and specificity differ substantially between assays; newer assays using recombinant antigens (e.g., NIE) perform better than others
Good and easy screening tool, especially in immunocompetent individuals and before immunosuppression is undertaken
False negatives in immunocompromised individuals may occur
Useful for followup after treatment, but it may take 12 months or longer to see a substantial fall in titer or to become negative

sect1.title: Screening of At-Risk Patients
sect1.para: Strongyloidiasis screening should be considered in the following:

listitem.para: Patients who are on or about to begin corticosteroid therapy or other immunosuppressants
Individuals known to have HTLV-1 infection
Patients with hematologic malignancies including leukemias and lymphomas
Patients who have had or are being considered for organ transplantation
Individuals with persistent peripheral or unexplained eosinophilia
Individuals with recent or remote travel histories to endemic areas, or areas with a known high prevalence of infection

sect1.para: Of note, though persons with HIV/AIDS can have disseminated strongyloidiasis or hyperinfection syndrome, observational studies have not shown an increased risk in this population (66).
For testing algorithms, see references11, 12, and 13.

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Strongyloides stercoralis infection should always be treated because of the potential for developing severe complicated disease. Ivermectin is the drug of choice. Repeated cycles of treatment may be required in immunocompromised patients. Ivermectin should not be used in pregnancy or in children <15 kg. Albendazole is less efficacious than ivermectin. Thiabendazole, although effective, is no longer used in many countries due to frequent severe side effects (see chapter 153 and references 1, 17, and 49).

Monitoring (usually 6 to 12 months after treatment) with serology, stool microscopy (if positive), and eosinophil count is recommended until infection is eradicated. Guidelines are available for refugees and migrants from countries of endemicity (4).
For a summary ofS. stercoralis, see Table 2 and Table 4.

sect2.title: STRONGYLOIDES FUELLEBORNI FUELLEBORNI AND STRONGYLOIDES FUELLEBORNI KELLYI
sect2.para: Strongyloides f. fuelleborni is a non-human primate parasite found in non-human primates in Africa and Asia. Most human infections are asymptomatic.

Strongyloides f. kellyi has only been reported from the island of New Guinea. This infection is thought to be asymptomatic in adults but may cause a severe protein-loss enteropathy and abdominal distension (“swollen belly syndrome”) in infants with high-worm-burden infections (67). In contrast to S. stercoralis, some ova of S. fuelleborni are found in feces in large numbers and resemble those of hookworms, but are smaller (45 to 55 μm by 30 to 35 μm) and contain a developing larva on passage (68).

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade I (Dorylaimia) of the Nematoda, in the order Trichocephalida and the family Trichuridae.

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: Eggs ofT. trichiura (Fig. 2G) are lemon shaped with a mucous plug at both ends and an unsegmented nucleus. Eggs have a double shell with the outer one bile-stained; they measure 50 to 55 by 20 to 24 μm. Under favorable conditions in soil, the eggs become fully embryonated and infective in 2 to 4 weeks.

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: Larvae emerge in the small intestine (the second-stage larvae measure about 260 by 15 μm in length). After a period of growth they pass into the cecum, where they embed in the mucosa.

sect2.title: Worms
sect2.para: Adult worms have a highly characteristic shape, from which the name whipworm is derived. The long, thin anterior end lies in a burrow in the mucosa, and the thicker end, which contains the reproductive tract, extends into the intestinal lumen. Worms are whitish; the males (30 to 45 mm) are shorter than the females (35 to 50 mm) and have a coiled posterior end. Adult females produce up to 20,000 eggs/day and live for approximately 3 years.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Prevention
sect1.para: Trichuris has a worldwide distribution and is often associated with Ascaris and hookworm infections in children and pregnant women in tropical and subtropical areas.
Preventive measures include health education about personal hygiene, avoidance of food and water with possible soil contamination, and drug therapy programs in areas where infection is endemic.

sect1.title: Transmission and Life Cycle (Fig. 10)
sect1.para: Transmission is direct via oral ingestion of embryonated eggs (infective stage) from contaminated soil. Following ingestion, larvae are released and pass into the large bowel, where they mature into adults in mucosal crypts. The eggs passed in feces contain an unsegmented ovum (diagnostic stage), and once the eggs are in warm, moist conditions in soil, they become infective 2 to 4 weeks after passage (Table 1). Rare zoonotic infections with the dog and pig whipworms, Trichuris vulpis and Trichuris suis, have been observed.
The prepatent period (from egg ingestion to egg production) is 3 months.

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: The clinical features are related to the intensity of infection; light infections are asymptomatic or present with mild gastrointestinal symptoms.

Epigastric pain, vomiting, distension, anorexia, and weight loss may occur with heavier infections, andTrichuris dysentery syndrome may be seen, in extreme cases complicated by rectal prolapse. Children with severe infections may develop growth retardation due to chronic malnutrition and iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). IDA may also occur in pregnant women with a higher worm burden, especially when hookworm coinfection is present (69). The mechanisms by which Trichuris infection causes anemia include blood loss from damage to the intestinal epithelium by adult worms, and infection-attributable loss of appetite resulting in lower food (and iron) intake. The health impact from T. trichiura rises as the worm burden increases and can result in chronic undernutrition. For more on the clinical manifestations of T. trichiura, see reference 17 and Table 2.
Peripheral blood eosinophilia may be seen at different stages of larval migration (Table 3).

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: The primary diagnosis of infection is by detection of eggs or DNA in feces. Multiple specimens collected on separate days may be required. Concentration methods such as formalin-ethyl acetate sedimentation or mini-FLOTAC should be used for optimal yield. The eggs are bile-stained and double walled with mucoid plugs at both ends, giving them a characteristic “tea tray” appearance (Fig. 2G).

figure.title: FIGURE 10 Life cycle of Trichuris trichiura. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.title: Macroscopic Examination
sect2.para: Adult worms are rarely passed in feces and are occasionally found on colonoscopy (70). They have a coiled, long, thin anterior region and a thicker tail, giving them the appearance of a stock whip (hence the name whipworm). The characteristic eggs may be seen in histological section (Fig. 5B).

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect2.para: Real-time PCR assays forT. trichiura are available, and it is detected by recently released commercial multiplex real-time PCR diagnostic assays (9). When performing real-time PCR for T. trichiura, the inclusion of a bead-beating step prior to fecal DNA extraction is imperative to ensure the sensitivity of the subsequent PCR assay (9).

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Albendazole or mebendazole are the drugs of choice (seechapter 153 and references 1 and 17), although efficacy is not satisfactory. Failures are not uncommon and multiple doses are required. Various combination chemotherapies have showed high efficacy, e.g., albendazole plus oxantel pamoate and albendazole (400 mg daily for 3 days) plus ivermectin (600 μg/kg daily for 3 days) (71–73). The benzimidazoles should not be used in the first trimester of pregnancy or in children <12 months of age. For a summary of T. trichiura, see Table 2 and Table 4.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Make note of the adequacy and quality of the specimen submitted. If an inadequate amount is submitted, mention it on the report.

Any helminth eggs or larvae found in feces are significant, and treatment is recommended even if the patient is asymptomatic. There is no need to quantitate helminth parasites in a diagnostic context, as this does not necessarily correlate with clinical illness. However, this may be required for epidemiological studies or for clinical assessment of children.

The time of collection is also important, especially whenEnterobius is suspected. If the specimen is inadequate, e.g., delayed, dry, or insufficient, a repeat specimen should be requested. A freshly collected specimen and/or use of preservative kits should be encouraged where possible. Nucleic acid detection can be variable and depends on stage of infection, the technique used for extraction, and the primers used.
Examples of interpretative comments used to ensure that adequate testing is performed are as follows.
1. Larvae ofS. stercoralis not detected. A single negative result does not exclude the diagnosis of Strongyloides. Please send freshly collected feces and transport to laboratory without delay.

2. Eggs ofE. vermicularis not detected on the sticky tape preparation. A single negative result does not exclude the diagnosis of pinworm infection. Please send properly collected repeat specimen, if clinically indicated. Contact the laboratory for instructions if required.
3. No parasites detected. Excretion of parasite forms may be variable or intermittent. Repeat testing is recommended if clinically indicated. Contact the laboratory for instructions if required.
4. Serology forStrongyloides stercoralis negative. In immunocompromised patients, feces examination of fresh specimen or a PCR is recommended.

5. Nucleic acid ofStrongyloides stercoralis not detected by PCR. Excretion of parasite forms may be variable or intermittent, or there may be inhibitors present in feces. Repeat testing is recommended if clinically indicated.
